description: From Middle English fansy, fantsy, a contraction of fantasy, fantasye, fantasie, from Old French fantasie, from Medieval Latin fantasia, from Late Latin phantasia (“an idea, notion, fancy, phantasm”), from Ancient Greek φαντασία (phantasía), from φαντάζω (phantázō, “to render visible”), from φαντός (phantós, “visible”), from φαίνω (phaínō, “to make visible”); from the same root as φάος (pháos, “light”); ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *bʰh₂nyéti, from the root *bʰeh₂- (“to shine”). Doublet of fantasia, fantasy, phantasia, and phantasy.

entries.meaning: Decorative, or featuring decorations, especially intricate or diverse ones.
examples: Synonyms: decorative, ornate
Antonyms: plain, simple
This is a fancy shawl.

entries.meaning: Of a superior grade.
examples: Synonym: high-end
This box contains bottles of the fancy grade of jelly.

entries.meaning: Executed with skill.
examples: He initiated the game-winning play with a fancy deked saucer pass to the winger.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Unnecessarily complicated.
examples: Synonym: highfalutin
Antonym: simple
I'm not keen on him and his fancy ideas.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Extravagant; above real value.
(nonstandard) In a fancy manner; fancily.
The imagination.
examples: Rustic females who habitually chew even pitch or spruce-gum are rendered thereby so repulsive that the fancy refuses to pursue the horror farther and imagine it tobacco  […]

entries.meaning: An image or representation of anything formed in the mind.
examples: Synonyms: conception, thought, idea

entries.meaning: An opinion or notion formed without much reflection.
examples: Synonym: impression

entries.meaning: A whim.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:whim
I had a fancy to learn to play the flute.

entries.meaning: Love or amorous attachment.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:predilection

entries.meaning: The object of inclination or liking.
Any sport or hobby pursued by a group.
examples: Synonyms: hobby; see also Thesaurus:hobby
Trainspotting is the fancy of a special lot.
the cat fancy

entries.meaning: The enthusiasts of such a pursuit.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:fan
He fell out of favor with the boxing fancy after the incident.

entries.meaning: A diamond with a distinctive colour.
That which pleases or entertains the taste or caprice without much use or value.
examples: London-pride is a pretty fancy, and does well for borders.

entries.meaning: A bite-sized sponge cake, with a layer of cream, covered in icing.
examples: a French fancy; a fondant fancy; cream fancies

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A sort of love song or light impromptu ballad.
In the game of jacks, a style of play involving additional actions (contrasted with plainsies).
examples: When you have mastered plainsies, the regular jack game, and have learned all the rules, you will be ready to use this part of the book. A fancy is a variation of plainsies which usually requires more skill than plainsies does.

description: From Middle English fancien, fantasien, fantesien, from Old French fantasier, from the noun (see above)).

verbs.description: fancy (third-person singular simple present fancies, present participle fancying, simple past and past participle fancied)

entries.meaning: (formal) To appreciate without jealousy or greed.
examples: I fancy your new car, but I like my old one just fine.

entries.meaning: (Britain) would like
examples: Synonym: feel like
I fancy a burger tonight for dinner.
Do you fancy going to town this weekend?

entries.meaning: (Britain, informal) To be sexually attracted to.
examples: Synonym: (US) like
I fancy that girl over there.

entries.meaning: (dated or in a set phrase) To imagine, suppose.
examples: [dated] I fancy you'll want something to drink after your long journey.
I fancy this is an error.
Fancy meeting you here!
Fancy that! I saw Elizabeth Bennett and Mr. Darcy kissing in the garden.
You won't get the gig just because you fancy yourself a musician.

entries.meaning: To form a conception of; to portray in the mind.
examples: Synonym: imagine

entries.meaning: To have a fancy for; to like; to be pleased with, particularly on account of external appearance or manners.
(transitive) To breed (animals) as a hobby.
examples: I would recommend this little book very highly to anyone who fancies pigeons, novices and veterans alike.
